resources.string: About AirCasting

AirCasting is a platform for recording, mapping, and sharing environmental data using your smartphone. Currently, AirCasters can upload sound level data recorded by their phone’s microphone. AirCasting is intended for measuring outdoor noise. Soon, we’ll expand the range of devices that plug into the AirCasting platform to include sound level meters and pollution sensors.

Each AirCasting session lets you capture real-world measurements, annotate the data to tell your story, and share it with a local and world-wide community via the CrowdMap. What was conjecture based on casual observation now becomes a measurable fact. For example, you might think: “This noisy neighborhood is disrupting my sleep.” Use AirCasting to identify the factual cause: “The twelve noise spikes greater than 65 decibels between 2am and 6am significantly degraded my quality of sleep.” When you share your AirCasting data with other AirCasters, your data and notes become a social statement, linking your experiences to the community’s observations.

We began AirCasting by measuring sound levels in New York City for three reasons:
1) New Yorkers care about neighborhood noise; it’s the #1 complaint filed with the City’s 311 hotline.
2) Unwanted noise negatively impacts people’s health.
3) Smartphones already have microphones, so no additional hardware is required.

Start measuring the air in your environment. What will you discover? What stories will you tell with AirCasting? Where’s the noisy corner or quiet sanctuary in your neighborhood? Together, with AirCasting, we can better understand and improve our environment.
Sound recording best practices

Follow the Sound Recording Best Practices guide if you intend to contribute your session to the AirCasting CrowdMap. If you’re not contributing your session to the CrowdMap, feel free to use AirCasting as you like. When recording sound level readings...

Do: measure outside, hold phone steady, talk quietly, walk quietly, craft a windscreen for your microphone (if possible)

Don’t: measure inside, put phone in pocket, talk loudly, walk loudly, expose your microphone to wind

Do you have an external sound level meter? Compare its readings with those from AirCasting to calibrate AirCasting. Under “settings”, adjust the “microphone maximum” until the readings on your phone match those from the external sound level meter. Then email us at info@habitatmap.org so we can add your phone to our microphone maximum database. To see a partial list of microphone maximums for different Android phones, visit our blog.

We welcome input for improving the Sound Recording Best Practices guide. Send feedback to info@habitatmap.org.
Start AirCasting

Make sure your GPS is on and your location on the map is accurate. Press the bullseye button to refresh your location and center the map. Don’t see any buttons? Just tap the screen once and they’ll appear; tap the screen again to make them disappear. When your location is accurate, press the “play” button to begin an AirCasting session.

First time? It’s a good idea to review the Sound Recording Best Practices guide before you start.
View the AirCasting Data

AirCasting displays data with three views: the Route Map, the CrowdMap, and the Graph. Toggle between the views by tapping the triangular buttons located on the left and right sides of the screen. If you don’t see any buttons tap the screen once to make them appear; tap the screen again to make them disappear.

The Route Map displays your current position as a colored dot with a white outline; dots without an outline are past readings. A dot’s color corresponds to the reading’s intensity at a location. Refer to the “Heat Legend ” (the colored bar at the top of the screen) to identify the intensity range for a reading. For example, a yellow dot corresponds to a sound level reading between 61 and 70 decibels.

The CrowdMap displays AirCasting data from all contributors. Each square’s color corresponds to the average intensity of all the readings recorded in that area. Refer to the “Heat Legend ” (the colored bar at the top of the screen) to identify the intensity range for a square. For example, an orange square corresponds to an average sound level between 71 and 80 decibels. If no colors are displayed, there is no data in that area. The CrowdMap might load slowly.

The Graph displays your sound level readings over time. Zoom in and out for more or less detail, respectively. Swipe to pan through the data.
Make a Note or Share a Reading
Tap the “share” button to add a note to a specific location or share your readings. The default message includes the peak and average decibel levels recorded over the last ten seconds.
Stop AirCasting
Press the “stop” button to end your session. Enter a title, tags, and description and press “Save session”.
Contribute to the CrowdMap

If you save a session, you can also contribute it to the CrowdMap. Sessions added to the CrowdMap are publicly accessible. Only press “yes” to contribute your session if it occurred outdoors and you made every effort to minimize interferences. Interference factors include wind on the microphone, clothing rubbing against the microphone, and loud conversation from the AirCasters. For more information, please review the Sound Recording Best Practices guide.
View Completed Sessions
Go to the “Sessions” screen and select a session to view.
Share, Edit, or Delete Sessions
Long press a past session to share, edit, or delete it. While viewing a session, share or edit it by pressing the corresponding buttons. You can share sessions as a web link or a CSV file.
Adjust the Heat Legend Units
Adjust the relationship between sound levels and display colors by either tapping the Heat Legend at the top of the screen or selecting it from the “Settings” screen.
Adjust the Microphone Maximum

Adjust the microphone maximum by navigating to the “Settings” screen. For most phones the microphone maximum is between 80 and 100 decibels. If you have access to a sound level meter, compare the readings with those from your phone, and then adjust the “microphone maximum” until the readings on your phone match those from the sound level meter.
Create a Profile or Sign in
You must be signed in to save and contribute your AirCasting sessions to the CrowdMap. Create a profile or sign in from the Settings screen.
Limitations

Sound level readings recorded by phone microphones may not always be accurate. In addition, AirCasters might contribute data to the AirCasting platform without following the Sound Recording Best Practices Guide. In the near term, we will work to increase the accuracy of the underlying data by improving the Sound Recording Best Practices Guide, creating mapping filters that can segregate and display data from selected AirCasters only, adjusting the default “microphone maximum” setting in the app to match the specifications of the Android device on which it is installed, and further developing the AirCasting app to receive data from sound level meters.
Health Effects of Noise Pollution

Noise is a major environmental issue, affecting large numbers of people, particularly in urban areas. Evidence from large-scale epidemiological studies links exposure to unwanted environmental noise with adverse health effects. Effects include cardiovascular disease, cognitive impairment, sleep disturbance, and tinnitus. Environmental noise should be viewed as a public health concern, not just as a nuisance. For more information on the health impacts of unwanted noise, visit the Environmental Protection Agency’s website, or read this report recently published by the World Health Organization: “Burden of disease from environmental noise”.
AirCasting is a HabitatMap Project

HabitatMap is a non-profit environmental health justice organization whose goal is to raise awareness about the impact the environment has on human health. We build tools to support grassroots environmental organizing, including HabitatMap.org - our community mapping platform - and AirCasting.
Open Source
AirCasting is an open source project. You can access the code repositories for the AirCasting Android app and the AirCasting web app through GitHub.

Built initially as a pavilion for the 1964 World\'s Fair, the New York Hall of Science is now New York City\'s hands-on science and technology center. Since 1986, NYSCI has served over seven million children, parents and teachers. NYSCI\'s mission is to convey the excitement and understanding of science and technology to children, families, teachers and others by galvanizing their curiosity and offering them creative, participatory ways to learn. NYSCI features the largest collection of hands-on science exhibits in New York City. Visitors of all ages can explore over 450 interactive exhibits.
